newsitem.title: USA: Healthdyne measure faces defeat - source.
newsitem.headline: Healthdyne measure faces defeat - source.

text.p: A legislative measure that would help Healthdyne Technologies Inc fight off a hostile takeover by Invacare Corp was not expected to reach a second vote in the Georgia Senate, a senior member of the chamber said on Thursday.
The senior Democrat told Reuters the amendment and the bill to which it was attached probably would not emerge from a House-Senate committee to be appointed later in the day.
Even if the measure did leave the committee and passed both the House and Senate, the official added, Georgia Gov. Zell Miller had vowed privately to veto it.
A spokesman for Miller said the governor had no comment about his position on the bill or the amendment.
"This is a red herring," said the Senate official, who asked not to be identified.
Thursday was expected to be the last day of the Georgia Legislature's 1997 session, with lawmakers remaining in their seats until as late as midnight.
The amendment, attached to a routine House bill in the Senate last week, would require publicly traded companies based in Georgia to stagger the election of directors.

Senators approved the legislation by a 52-1 vote on Friday. But the House, which had already approved the bill without the amendment, disagreed with the changes on Tuesday. That sent the measure to a conference committee which still had not been appointed by late morning.

Meanwhile, the legislative advisor who authored the underlying piece of legislation, which would modify the state business code, said none of the changes need to be approved this year. "There's nothing in here that is time sensitive," said William Carney, Emory University professor of corporate finance, an advisor to the bill's sponsor, Rep. Jim Martin.
